title: Frank Warren admits Tyson Fury’s stint on WWE is ‘risky’ amid injury recovery
text:
Fury has now appeared twice on WWE and brawled with Braun Strowman (Picture: WWE)

Frank Warren praised Tyson Fury’s forray into WWE as a promotional masterstroke, but conceded he would have preferred his heavyweight concentrated on his injury recovery.

Fury surprised everyone in boxing with two appearances on WWE in the last week, sparking a mass brawl on Raw on Monday night.

The Gypsy King has developed a beef with Braun Strowman and the two men had to be held back by dozens of wrestlers as they tried to attack each other during their latest encounter.

Fury suffered two deep cuts above his eye in his last boxing fight against Otto Wallin last month and risked opening up those gashes when arms were flailing during the melee with Strowman.

And while the heavyweight’s promoter was not against his fighter’s crossover into the world of wrestling, Warren admitted he was a worried man watching the scenes unfold on Raw.

‘Tyson Fury loves it,’ Warren told Metro.co.uk. about the guest appearances on WWE.

‘That brawl clip doing the rounds on social media has something like 4million views. Madness.

‘His profile gets bigger every time and he’s doing us promoters a real favour by going on WWE.

‘But truthfully, I don’t like the risk of his cut opening up. Tyson’s a law unto himself. It’s risky though, no doubt about that.

‘In an ideal world I’d prefer he didn’t do it, but it’s all about the bigger picture for him. He’s a natural wrestling star.’

Fury has a particular dislike for Strowman (Picture: WWE)

Fury called Strowman out again on social media, urging the 6ft 8in giant to agree to fight him.

‘Let me know when you want more of these hands,’ Fury tweeted after coming to blows with the WWE star.

Asked if Fury had a future in WWE and if a showdown with Strowman could actually happen, Warren replied: ‘I’m still awaiting the call from Tyson to tell me he’s finished with this WWE stuff.’

While speculation continues Fury could make further appearances on WWE, the former unififed heavyweight world champion is scheduled to take on Deontay Wilder next February in their much-anticipated rematch.

Fury and his team have repeatedly downplayed concerns he may not be fully fit for the rematch, but he will not be able to resume sparring until December at the earliest.
